abstract.text: Inset group of top, bottom, leading and trailing.
Factory to create a new InsetGroup instance with
an edge and an inset. (Can be used with reduce.)
Return self with top, bottom, leading, trailing values rounded
to specified number of decimal “places”.
Convert this InsetGroup to an inverted InsetGroup
effectively an “OutsetGroup”, by negating all values.
Total of insets for axis.
Total of horizontal insets, if they exist.
Treat this inset group’s leading/trailing values as
left/right, respectively, regardless of layout direction.
Since ltr layouts are already that way, this just switches
leading/trailing if the layout is rtl.
Convert this InsetGroup to provide insets only on
the provided axis.
Return self only if there is (at least one of) top, bottom, leading or trailing values
Given a layout direction return the value that would
be used on the left (leading for ltr and trailing for rtl).
Top, bottom, leading and trailing values are all 0.0
Number of existing insets on this InsetGroup
represented as a Pair. For x or y, it will
be either 0, 1 or 2 insets.
Does this inset group have insets that match
a specific corner.
Export this InsetGroup to an axis
based on existing values on either axis.
E.g. if only “top” has a value this returns vertical axis.
Given a set of edge offsets, make a radius
concentric to conform to these offsets.
Export this InsetGroup to an Offset representation
with x being the total horizontal insets
and y being the total vertical insets.
Return self only if at least one of top, bottom, leading or trailing have a non-zero value.
Given a layout direction return the value that would
be used on the right (trailing for ltr and leading for rtl).
Export this InsetGroup to NSDirectionalEdgeInsets
convertin all nil values to 0.0.
This NS object respects layout direction.
Global inset assumes all insets are set, and are of the same value.
Inset Group with all insets set to 0.0
BEWARE: 0.0 insets are actually what you want.
See also InsetGroup.empty, which sets all to nil.
Get the corresponding inset value for specified edge.
Export these insets as margin wrappers.
Export this InsetGroup into UIEdgeInsets
respecting layout direction.
Top, bottom, leading and trailing values are all nil.
is a Swift framework for developing apps on iOS and iPadOS.
Given an existing
create an inset group
based on a fixed
inset (top and/or bottom)
and calculate the horizontal inset (leading and trailing)
to result in an overall size (after applying the group)
that conforms to the provided aspect
relative
to the cross axis (i.e. height * ratio = width).
By default the leading and trailing insets will be equal
so as to achieve the aspect ratio but this can be
tweaked by specifying a percentage value via
wherein the total horizontal inset
should split.
Examples: 0% = no leading inset (all inset would be applied
to trailing); 100% = all inset value would be applied
to the leading inset; 50% (the default) = evenly split
leading/trailing insets; etc.
This can also be specified in absolute points.
Examples: 0.0 = no leading inset with all remaining
inset applied to trailing; 20.0 = leading inset
of 20.0 and remaining inset applied to trailing; etc.
(NOTE: Absolute points that exceed the total computed
horizontal inset will provide consistent results by
inverting the opposing inset by the remaining amount.)
Export this InsetGroup to UIEdgeInsets
converting all nil values to 0.0.
Assumes leading == left and trailing == right.
See also “ns” version that respects layout direction.
Return inset group with nil values represented as 0.0
(while retaining other non-nil values as-is)
Export this InsetGroup to a HorizontalInset
representing the leading/trailing values.
Export InsetGroup for use with pinning.
This factory inverts bottom and trailing values to work
correctly with pinning operations. This way, the original
values at the callsite can be normal/positive values,
which is just like how edge insets work.
Given an existing
create an inset group
based on a fixed
inset (leading and/or trailing)
and calculate the vertical inset (top and bottom)
to result in an overall size (after applying the group)
that conforms to the provided aspect
relative
to the cross axis (i.e. width * ratio = height).
By default the top and bottom insets will be equal
so as to achieve the aspect ratio but this can be
tweaked by specifying a percentage value via
wherein the total vertical inset
should split.
Examples: 0% = no top inset (all inset would be applied
to the bottom); 100% = all inset value would be applied
to the top inset; 50% (the default) = evenly split
top/bottom insets; etc.
This can also be specified in absolute points.
Examples: 0.0 = no top inset with all remaining
inset applied to the bottom; 20.0 = top inset
of 20.0 and remaining inset applied to bottom; etc.
(NOTE: Absolute points that exceed the total computed
vertical inset will provide consistent results by
inverting the opposing inset by the remaining amount.)
Inset Group with all insets set to nil
Export this InsetGroup to a Size representation
with width being the total horizontal insets
and height the total vertical insets.
Export this InsetGroup to an OffsetPair
representing the first values of the coordinate
space – top and leading: for x and y respectively.
Total of vertical insets, if they exist.
Total of all insets, if they exist.
Inset group of top, bottom, leading and trailing.
Reverse the values of this inset group on an axis or both axes,
for example swapping top and bottom and/or swapping leading and trailing.
Export this InsetGroup to a VerticalInset
representing the top/bottom values.
Export this InsetGroup to an OffsetPair
representing the last values of the coordinate
space – bottom and trailing: for x and y respectively.
Clamp this InsetGroup by minimum and/or maximum insets.
The average inset value of
insets.
Example: if only top and bottom are specified then
the average is based on those two values only –
i.e. it does not treat leading/trailing as 0s.
top:10, bottom:10, average is 10 not 5.
(Nils are never treated as equivalent to 0.0.)
